snippet: With the peace process stalled, analysts see nonviolent resistance as a critical tactic for the Palestinian national movement.
abstract: More than 1,500 Palestinians in Israeli jails join a hunger strike to demand improved prison conditions; with the peace process stalled, many analysts see this nonviolent resistance as a critical tactic for the Palestinian national movement, and a potential catalyst to bring an Arab Spring-style uprising to the West Bank. Photos (M)/

byline.original: By JODI RUDOREN; Khaled Abu Aker contributed reporting from Ramallah, West Bank, and Rina Castelnuovo from Ramle, Israel

lead_paragraph: KHARAS, West Bank -- The newest heroes of the Palestinian cause are not burly young men hurling stones or wielding automatic weapons. They are gaunt adults, wrists in chains, starving themselves inside Israeli prisons. Each day since April 17, scores of Palestinian prisoners have joined a hunger strike that officials say now counts more than 1,500 participants. And on Thursday, the Palestinian Authority's minister of detainees said that if Israel did not yield to their demands for improved prison conditions, the remaining 3,200 would soon join in.

headline.main: Palestinians Go Hungry To Make Their Voices Heard

keywords.value: MIDDLE EAST AND NORTH AFRICA UNREST (2010- )
